Then tie it over the flesh that is against the bone, and extend its end to pull the flesh downwards; and you will uncover the flesh above the place you wish to tighten, so as not to harm the cut with pressure.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board under the lower bone precisely; for when you do this, it does not prevent but rather cuts the rotten flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that the tightening be over the rotten place for a little while, so that there is no collapse of the bones; and it does not appear in its appearance to the senses, and it prompts another turn to tighten itself.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If a bone is corrupted and not protruding, then that part continues to be joined with the rest; the corruption is either in the middle or in some part of it. Then, remove all the flesh from those parts.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then apply the lower splint.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then, from the affected part on the first side, cut it with a saw until the joint continues from the other side; and make the lock according to the length of the corruption, as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is in the joint, cut that corrupted joint and saw through the bone where it continues from the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If the corruption is indeed in the continuity of two joints, then there is no skill involved except for filing.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the thumb or toe joint, then the case becomes very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	Indeed, it is necessary for you to inquire about the nature of the corruption as it appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And file it, and clean the affected area as best as you can, using any tool at your disposal; when it no longer causes any conflict with a vein or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And you should know that there are many cutting tools and saws for cutting these bones, according to the position of the bone, and their preparation, and the thickness of them, and their size, and their lightness or heaviness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore, it is necessary to prepare the instruments suitable for every kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations will indicate to you the nature of the instrument you need when you have a long study with it.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of these methods is a testament to the ways of illness; for then you will find within yourself what suits him from among the instruments for every disease.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am firming up for you in the conclusion of this chapter the number of instruments, which you will use as examples on which to cut and the proof by which you will experience over others.
Forma Serrae.	The shape of the saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of the other saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of the other saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the saw is depicted, made to be centered.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Make the bow of it curve upwards, its edge sharp as iron, and its handle out of boxwood, and have it shaped pyramidally in the center.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The form of the intersecting rasors.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	This is the head of the rasor, according to the form of the locked star's head; and its points are according to the form of the elischefgi's points.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not fit unless the heads of the intersecting rasors rub against it, when they are bent or corrupted, or if the mouth is wide and large.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The form of the larger rasor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of the medium rasor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The form of the rasor's side.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The form of the rasor where it is concave.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The form of the other rasor's fine point.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The form of the other rasor's curved extremity.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The form of the surgical cut, a delicate tentation.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The manner in which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The form of the great cut as well.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a key, and its end is like a saw; it appears in many places for the reason of the bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The form of the cut that relates to the reason it is pierced through bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its end is triangular, the tips are sharp.
Fit ex Indi.	It fits from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly, it is necessary that all we have said about cuts, incisions, and saws be done.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	**On the cut of extremities and the locking of bones.**
Caput LXXXIX.	Head 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities putrefy, either from an external cause or an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When, therefore, you have medicated that corruption with the cure of medicines, and it does not yield to treatment, and you see that the corruption has spread to a member, without anything being affected by it, then you must cut off that member up to where the corruption follows, so that the patient is freed from death or from the evil which is greater than the defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this has occurred is that the member becomes discolored until it can be burned or rotten after turning black; until that rot is cut off where it follows the member and spreads throughout the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, when making the proper cut, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is due to the impact of some venomous creatures such as a scorpion, or a viper, or a leech, and others like them.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption or impact is in the tip of a finger, then cut off the finger, and do not leave space for the corruption to spread to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut it off at the base of the finger, and do not leave space for the corruption to spread until it reaches the wrist.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it spreads abruptly, then cut off the arm near the elbow at its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the corruption spreads and you see it around the elbow, then that is the death of the patient.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And beyond that care for healing, it is the quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly for the foot, when there is an unexpected corruption in a finger, then cut it off at one of the joints; and if it affects the nail of the foot, then cut off the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	However, if it ascends to the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If the corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill left, except to sever it and let the disabled one die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the manner of cutting off the member, or severing it itself, is such that you tighten the ligament below, which you wish to cut, and loosen another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let the assistant stretch one ligament down below, and let another assistant stretch a ligament above upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the whole flesh is detached.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it is cut or tied off.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you cover all parts with a linen cloth, and do not allow the knife to touch any healthy place; and cause an addition of injury to the sick, and a hot aposteme.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, a flow of blood occurs internally while you are operating, cauterize the site quickly or place on it certain powders that stop the bleeding.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then prepare for your treatment until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the injured member with a suitable ligature and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you about what happened to a man on his foot, the same thing that I am telling you about.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	This is because a blackness occurred on his foot due to heating similar to burning from fire; that damage first occurred on his finger, until it spread throughout the entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	The man therefore tended to himself, after he saw the damage occurring in his member due to the intensity of its pain, and the heat it encountered; and it affected him near the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed for him, the same damage occurred to his index finger.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I tried to recover that excess with what I placed on his hand from medications after cleansing his body; but the excess did not cease, and it started spreading to other fingers, until the damage spread throughout the hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He therefore called on me to cut off his hand, and I did not wish to do so, hoping that by doing so I could avoid the consequences of that surplus [tissue], but I also feared death for him at the very moment of cutting off his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Since the virtue of the man was superior to the case.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he had lost hope in me, he returned to his land, and later came back to me because of his condition, and cut off his entire hand; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not narrate this story except to serve as an aid regarding what happens in this condition, and to explain its meaning so that it is understood according to how it is done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	§ On the care of wounds and the quality of enemas with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in certain fleshy members and the space of the abscess extends until it forms a collection of pus, then later it ruptures or perforates, and whatever is within it from the pus comes out, leaving a hollow place as if it were a cavity; and the skin over it becomes thin like a cloth that has been worn thin: and it does not reach its ultimate state of corruption, nor does it affect the mouth, nor the nerves, nor the ligaments. It deserves to be called an abscess, and not a fistula; however, if the space of the abscess extends until it affects some of these members, then it is called a fistula or ulcer.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the treatment for it is to incise that skin entirely as it has been weakened: and especially when it has become thin and like cloth, and you can be sure that it will not adhere to the place because of its own corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	However, if you hope that it will adhere to the skin and this final corruption does not result from it, and if there is thickening of the skin due to flesh, then treat it with a clister; and it is as if you were considering the sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then, if it is large and the pus that is released from it has a bad odor, then clisterize it with Egyptian medicine, which consists of equal parts of vinegar, oil, and zinnia, mix them together for use, and heat them over fire until the medicine turns red, and it will become thick like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what is necessary and dissolve it in water and honey, and clisterize the sinus with it; then close its opening and leave the medicine inside for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression; do this every day until the sinus is purified and the bad odor is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when you clisterize with ash water if this medicine is not available to you; and it is as if you were to take ashes from burning wood or ashes from holly wood, and throw water over them.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then take it and wash with it, until you trust that the sinus is already cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient cannot tolerate either the Egyptian remedy or water with ashes, then wash it with water and honey, to which something from crushed cumin has already been mixed.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or wash it with honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey to cleanse and wash away, and wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is an excess of tightness and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	Do this several times, and trust that the corruption of the sinus is already removed; then wash it with what makes the flesh in it come to life.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is, that you take from the paste of dyafinicon; and dissolve it in rose oil, and astringent wine; or wash it with certain medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I have written in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the orifice of the sinus is tight, through which the cannula for enema does not pass, then enlarge it with a knife; or put in it a moist lint in Egyptian ointment, or basilicon ointment, until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the orifice is also wide, then add its lips with a stitch; and allow out of it as much as enters for enema without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And likewise, if the opening from which purulent matter flows is raised towards the higher parts, it should be cut in the lower part where it is located, so that the purulent matter can flow out of it to the lower parts; for when purulent matter becomes confined in a deep sinus, it prevents the generation of flesh within it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to cut the sinus around its lower part as you wish, then try to prepare the member in such a way that the purulent matter can flow out of it easily according to what you have prepared.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try not to retain any purulent matter within it at all, and take the consolidative medicines placed on the wound, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over the linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such a size that it makes communication with the entire sinus possible.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then, using scissors, cut directly into the opening of the sinus's foramen, making it slightly larger than the original opening of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend another linen cloth with unguents according to the size of the foramen, and place it on top of the previous one at a distance from the opening of the sinus, allowing the escape of purulent matter from it; but do not remove the large cloth unless after some days, once.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is above the opening of the sinus, it is he who moves at every hour to allow what has accumulated in it to come out; and you should know that the amount of fluid that flows from it can be great or small, or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And consider again the place of the sinus itself; does its lord feel pain there, or is there no pain, and is there a discharge, or is there none?
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment is carried out thus, and you see the material coming out from the opening of the sinus, then know that the sinus has adhered or is close to adhesion; then resolve it in the morning, or on the third day; and when you have healed the wound, then change the bandage, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	However, if a subtle fluid comes out from the sinus after a long space of time, then do not despair about its adhesion, for healing is approaching, since there are people whose flesh takes a long time to heal in their wounds, and others who act contrary to that.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If however, after many days, undigested pus comes out from the sinus, then know that the sinus is not adhering.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If therefore the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its condition prolonged, then add to the drying medicines, true physicians, that their substance may be humid, and their virtue dry; such as dyeing ointment, when a surplus addition is made to it from the skin.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last of the more important ones that it treats, it is to take a dyeing ointment and dissolve it in rose oil, and then apply it over the top of the ancient equal wine in its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then make it into a paste with it and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it does this similar action when you do not have the dyeing ointment available, using honey instead, after heating it until it thickens, and then using it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, aloe, and frankincense: mix them all together, and sprinkle it over the honey while it is still on the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then cover it with a cloth and squeeze it over the sinuses, and mix the honey you have heated until it thickens with it, until it becomes thick: then sprinkle the mixture over the top and place the cloth on top and squeeze it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when it is administered with the long wormwood and the roots of the heavenly lily, and there is a lily, and flour of herb and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple or mixed, squeeze it and sprinkle over the honey I described, and use that.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the condition of the sinuses does not improve with this treatment, then know that there is corruption within it, or it has already left an impression on the bones, or on the hard remaining members, or on the ligaments, then treat it with the fistular cure as mentioned above.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	On the treatment of panaritis and the application of ointments, the addition of a cut digit, and amputation.
Caput XCI.	Head XCI.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritis is an abscess that arises under the thumb nail of the hand or foot, and perhaps in other digits as well.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When this condition is prolonged and its treatment neglected, the abscess becomes heated and infected; it decays, emitting pus until it corrodes the root of the nail, or perhaps corrupts the entire digit, spreading as far as the bone, until it emits a foul odour; and the extremity of the finger becomes enlarged, and takes on a dark colour.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When, therefore, you treat it as we have described in amputation, and your treatment does not remove the excess, then it is necessary to cut with a knife the entire remaining part of the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	Cauterization, indeed, is very useful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If the bone is indeed healthy and the nail still intact but the edge cuts into the flesh and begins to pierce it, then you must place a thin beam under the angle of the nail that is piercing the flesh, and push it upwards; cut the flesh easily with this, and put over what remains of the flesh from burning medicines, until it is entirely removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then, care for it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	However, if the corruption has already affected the mouth, then it is necessary to cut that part of the mouth and remove the affected tissue; for it will never heal as long as the corrupted tissue remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you observe that the corruption is progressing to the finger, then cut it off at the joint, as mentioned in the previous advice.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however, the nail becomes frayed or struck, and it causes extreme pain, then it is necessary to use a leech to draw blood from the affected part first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail using a sharp spatula, cutting across it from top to bottom.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And take care, so that the cut does not reach the flesh beneath the nail; for you will cause greater pain to the affected part, and it will impede healing at the site.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the site with something that soothes pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The true finger that is born in some hands of men may be entirely fleshy; and perhaps there are bones in some of them, or maybe it has a nail; and some of them are born at the root of the joint, or their origin is in certain knots on the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, he who is born with certain finger nodes does not move, and he who is born near the joint of the finger perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, he who is among them (the fingers) is fleshy, his section (amputation) is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	Which is, as you cut into the same near its root with a broad spatula-like instrument.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	However, the one whose birth is at the joint's root, its treatment (healing) is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, abstain from cutting it (the finger) off.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In him who is born in a finger near the last node, then it is necessary to cut into his flesh first with a round (incision) up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then, saw the bone with one of those saws suitable for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it (the wound) until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	The healing that occurs in the fingers, however, often happens due to either birth (present from birth) or from the healing of a wound or burn and similar conditions.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, it is necessary to remove that consolidation until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them a thin layer of lead or soaked cloth in rose oil, so that they do not adhere quickly, and separate them; or place between them a thin sheet of lead, until the place is consolidated as necessary.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And likewise, if there is a consolidation of certain fingers with the palm, then dry that consolidation according to what has been prepared and suits the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	§ On the incision of defects.
Caput XCII.	Head 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	These are veins that are inflated, thick, filled with melancholic excesses which occur in many parts of the body; and their flow is greatest in the legs, especially in the legs of those who walk and work, and bear weight.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary to administer purgation of the body from black cholera several times with strong purging.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then make bloodletting on the veins of the patient with a lancet.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these conditions with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	It is one of them, so that they may be bled, and black blood is extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And another method is that the vein is made to pulsate, and all of it is extracted.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The true section of it is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	It cuts the leg first with much hot water until the thick, foul blood is resolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then it tightens the leg of the patient from the lower part of the thigh to the lower part of the leg with bandages.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then it dries the vein at one, or two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then it makes it pulsate, that is, extracts the blood in your hand from the lower part of the leg upwards, and you must cut the vein at the top with a phlebotome first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then apply ointment to the lower part until enough blood has drained out as you see fit, and as much as the patient's strength allows.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Afterwards, bind it and strictly advise the patient to refrain from foods that cause black cholera, and repeat the evacuation and phlebotomy when the veins are filled and it causes harm to the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The preparation of this substance is as follows.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	If there are many hairs in the wound, remove them.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce the tip into a bath; or use a sharp instrument to puncture the leg with warm water until it turns red and the veins bulge; or perform vigorous exercise if there is no hot bath available, until the limb is heated.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin with a clean cloth along the length of the vein; or at its end near the knee, or at the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with forceps and strip away the vein from all sides until it becomes visible; and at its appearance, you will see it turn red and then darken.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When therefore the vein has been withdrawn from the skin, you will see it as white as if it were a chord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert the blade underneath until it is completely removed from the skin; suspend it gently with a hook and let it drain.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry another section near that one with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then strip the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then elevate it with the rods as you did before, and suspend it with another hook as you did initially.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then cut another section, or multiple sections, as needed.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate it again, and make an incision on the last section near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then extract it towards the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you have extracted it from the upper section or all higher sections, then make an incision on it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If, however, it does not obey you when extracting and elevating, then insert a sharp two-edged blade and tie it, and extract it by force: or insert under it a rod, and turn your hand to every part until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be careful, so that it does not get cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it gets cut, it will be difficult for you to elevate it, and the injury will spread from that point.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So when you have completely extracted it: then place over the wound a bandage soaked in rose oil or oil, and tend to it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vessel (i.e., the vein or artery) is contracted due to a twist, and this twist needs to be corrected to reach its parts, and it is not as we said according to rectitude, then one must find a way over it to every part of its twist, and the places where its own untwisting should occur.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with hooks until you have entirely extracted it; and be careful not to cut the vein or injure it near your section, for it will be difficult to lift or extract it afterward.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, be careful with your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The shape of the incident that heals the vessel.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The shape of the nearby blind (i.e., blocked or obstructed) vessel.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not as hard as the other vessels, nor does it have sharp ends that would injure a vein; instead, it is of great flexibility and softness. If it were thin, it could pierce the vein with its thinness, but on the contrary, it has excessive thickness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the vein of the thigh.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in hot lands, such as those of Alizegis and the Arab land, and in dry, hot lands with little tenderness, that is, where grass or trees do not grow.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And indeed, its generation is from the putrefaction that occurs beneath the skin, as happens within the bodies of snakes and tapeworms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the onset of the course of this vein is what happens in the leg with a severe inflammation.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	It then becomes narrowed.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to exit from that narrowed place, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When it therefore appears from that end, then you should cover that segment with lead, whose weight is a keil of a drachma, up to two drachmas and the spot itself; and let the lead be suspended from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever anything emerges from that [vein] towards the outside, cover it with lead and seal that spot.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it is prolonged much, then cut off that part and sew up the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it completely until it has come out entirely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it, it contracts and goes into the flesh, causing an ulcer and puttingrefaction in that place, making a bad wound.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore, it should be treated gently and extracted gradually until the last part comes out from its place, and nothing remains of that in the body: and from this vein, in some people, flows a blood vessel five palms long and ten, in length.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has reached me, because a man has come out from twenty palms (or fingers).
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	However, if it is cut during your treatment time: then insert a probe into its opening and make a long hole with the body, until all that is in it of matter is evacuated, and administer treatment to the place's putrefaction with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care with the cure for the ulcers.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot or in the foot itself; and it has many openings, and a branch goes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore, treat it as we have said in the division and with what has been mentioned above.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	On the division of worms generated under the skin, and it is said to be a "boil.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This boil is called a "boil" in some lands among us: for it often happens with cows, and it is a small worm, which is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it crawls throughout the body, ascending and descending: and it is seen by the sense when it moves from one part to another, until it breaks apart wherever it breaks in the skin and comes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the putrefaction of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As worms and snakes, that is, roundworms (lumbrics) and hookworms occur in the intestine.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And fear is from its evil.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	For when it crawls throughout the body and ascends to the head, and reaches a place, then perhaps it opens within and comes out, and destroys the eye: and that happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore you wish to cure him and extract it, then that can only be done during his walking and the appearance of it to the sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary to tie what is above it and what is below it with a strong ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry it above and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it is deeply inserted into the flesh and you cannot find it, then place a cautery on the spot with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And worse than that, it is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	However, if you see it has already reached the head near the eye, then tighten a good strain under it above the eyebrow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry it above and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary for the patient to use purification of his body with medicines that dissolve bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And he should beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the cutting of a wound according to Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter XCV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This affliction is called Nakir in our land: it is a pain that occurs in certain members (limbs), and then it spreads from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And indeed, I have seen it myself, according to what I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I have been called to attend a sick woman in certain parts (of her body).
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she exposed her arm, and I saw a slight swelling in the vein at the end of her arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after remaining for an hour, I saw one swelling move with a quickness, like a bowstring moving up towards her shoulder more quickly than it can be said; so that it looks like living silver running from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore the pain subsided from that place and it became fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then after an hour had passed, it became still, and it moved into the rest of her body, until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	He then told me that it was turned inside out throughout his entire body, as I could see.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed, therefore, at the speed with which he moved from one part of the body to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I, indeed, had not before seen this sickness with my own eyes in such a way according to this manner.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I have seen many who discover the pain changing from one part of the body to another; and not see it with their eyes as they see it in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that this is otherwise than because she was a woman among those who are discovered to have such dry body passages; from here, therefore, appears to the senses that change of air took place.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and have humid bodies, hidden passages.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	So if you see the cure for it and the patient feels that pain, then if it is apparent to you as we said, then tighten above and below it quickly; and dry above it until that air released by constriction comes out; and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If, however, you do not see it with your own eyes: then care for it with the discharge of the body, and with what it expels air currents, and poultices them with foul-smelling pills, and pills of serpentine, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the extraction of sagittas (arrows)
Caput XCVI.	**Chapter XCI: On the Head**
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows (sagittas) differ according to their kinds, and also according to the places from which they exit from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	The true diversity of these (arrows) is that some have large barbs, and others have few; some are pointed, and others blunt.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And among them (arrows) are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And from them (arrows) there are those that have barbs.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And from them (arrows) there are those that have stars (or points).
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	These (arrows), indeed, according to the members (or parts) from which they exit, are according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or these (members) are indeed from the main, concave members, such as the brain, and heart, and spleen, and lung, and kidney, and intestines, and similar organs.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it (the arrow) exits from any of these members, and you see signs of death (as I will tell you later), then you must strive to extract that arrow from them, for death follows it where it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs do not appear to you, and there is no arrow hidden deeply within the member, then extract it and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when an arrow falls into the brain and penetrates a bone, and emerges on top of the brain, it is—since these things happen from that strong blow, and darkness, and giddiness, and redness in the eyes, and swelling, and redness of the tongue, and spasms, and confusion of mind, and choleraic vomiting.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood may emerge from the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech may be lost, and voice destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And from the site of the wound, white humidity resembling pus emerges.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it exits from that, resembling the moisture of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not emerge.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow when it falls into the heart are as follows: that it is near the left breast; and it feels as if it were firmly fixed in a hard substance, not in something hollow.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the movement of the arrow is similar to the movement of the pulse: and blood flows out from the wound black.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And this follows with chillness of the extremities, cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Therefore know that death descends without doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of the arrow when it strikes the lung is the spurting outflow of blood from the wound; and the limbs that follow, they turn pale, and the color changes to blue.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And the great, deep breath departs; and it seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into a wound within the chest, then it is near the small ribs; and this causes almost all of the upper body's limbs to move, with great pain and a deep breath.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested will emerge from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow strikes the abdomen and becomes lodged there, then something like feces or bile will emerge from the wound, or even broken intestines.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope for his recovery, nor for the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow falls into the bladder and urine flows out, and something comes from it to the outside, and the pain grows stronger over the injured part, then know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining members, such as the face, neck, throat, ribs, sternum, backbones, furca, coxa, leg, and foot, along with similar parts from other members, are to be treated in many ways according to their positions; when the arrow does not hit an artery or nerve, and is not a deadly arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I have seen these arrows to be as if they point to a sign for your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Which is the case because an arrow struck a man's eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	I therefore extracted it from his other side, beneath his ear fat; and he was healed, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had struck him in his eye fat below his lower eyelid; and the arrow was already hidden, and I could not get it out except for a small part of its tip, with which it was stuck in its wood; and this was a large arrow among the arrows of the Turks, with soft iron, without ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	Health is thus achieved by the Jew, and no evil befalls him through his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of the Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabian arrow, and it is that which has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	I therefore followed along over that same between the two guides: and it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I was therefore subtile with it, until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from the man which had fallen into his belly: and we thought, because he was perishing from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	Afterward, when thirty days had passed, and nothing had changed over him regarding his condition from following the arrow; I pondered over it, and extracted it, and he was healed, and no evil befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw the man to whom the arrow had struck his back, and the wound was healed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	Afterward, therefore, after seven years, the arrow came out at the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman whose bowstring had pierced her belly, and the wound was healed over it, but the bowstring remained inside: and nothing changed from its original position, and the woman found no harm from any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man whose bowstring struck him in the face; the wound healed, but he did not feel much pain, and similar cases are numerous.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted a bowstring from a man who had been struck in the middle of his nose, and it was already shifting towards the right side: and the bowstring was completely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore called upon to treat him after the bowstring injury for up to three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I therefore found the wound from the bowstring to be very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I therefore examined it with a delicate probe, and I did not feel it; he himself, however, felt a pricking and pain beneath the skin on his right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore hoped that it was the tip of the bowstring causing that puncture.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore applied a poultice to the place, using one with strong drawing and healing properties, confident that the swelling would go down and I would see a sign of the bowstring's path, so that I could cut it out above it; but nothing happened at the site that indicated the bowstring had been embedded there.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	Therefore, he applied an emplaster to it for many days, and no complication arose, and the wound became consolidated; yet the patient remained weak from the extraction for some time, until on a certain day he felt an arrow inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	He then told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I then applied a sharp, corrosive medicine to the wound for many days until it opened; and when I tried to pull out the arrow, I felt the fine tip of it still adhering to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added more of that sharp medicine to the opening of the wound until we could see the end of the arrow; and it took about four months for me to remove it with him.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then, after the wound had healed enough, and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, I tried to turn and move it, but it did not yield; then I did not cease trying subtilely and ingeniously on it with means of mechanisms until one day, when I properly formed the forceps according to their final shape in a chapter, I managed to extract it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I healed the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the doctors judged that the nose cartilage would not heal.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I therefore restored it, and the wound became healed and strengthened, and the sick was made whole with complete health: not a thing at all harmed it.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you the quality of removing some arrows: so that you apply that rule and meaning to what I have not said.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and the distinctions thereof are not comprehended with narration; nor does that book comprehend it, and a prudent artisan compares with little to much, and with what is present to what is absent, and he finds a new operation and a new instrument among the descent of external things in this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not emerge from the members in which they are fixed, unless according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or through attraction from the place from which it entered inside.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or conversely of the other part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out where it entered, or is an arrow proceeding in the flesh, and is attracted, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	Which if it does not obey to coming out from the time in which it fell, then you must let that one go for a few days, until the flesh around it putrefies; and its attraction is released, and its coming out.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And likewise if it is fixed in the bone and does not obey you to come out, then leave it for several days, and repeat the process of drawing and moving it every day until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If after several days it still does not obey you to come out, then you must drill around the arrow in the bone from all sides with a fine knife until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out and extract the arrow.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	However, if the arrow is fixed in the skull and has already penetrated into one of the brain's ventricles, and symptoms of some of the conditions I mentioned appear, then refrain from drawing the arrow and leave it until it becomes suitable to be drawn out after several days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the brain tissue, then death is not prolonged for it.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, except only within a bone and does not penetrate to the brain tissue; and he remains weak for several days, without any of those conditions happening to him, then apply your skills in drawing and extracting the arrow.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	However, if it is fixed strongly and does not obey you when drawn, then apply a knife around the arrow as described, using a wooden board; then tend to the wound until healing occurs.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow is already concealed within the body and is hidden and disguised from the senses, then search for it with your probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with instruments that are suitable for attracting it.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you cannot reach it due to the compression of the wound and the depth of the arrow, and there are no bones, nerves, or vessels there: then find a place above it until the wound expands and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If there are any other parts that should be held onto, then release the fixed flesh from all sides using every means and tool at your disposal, until it becomes possible to dislodge the arrow without damaging the bones or distorting them.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you perform the extraction of the arrow, wherever it may be located, then use a twisting movement of your hand, along with pincers for all parts, until you make it come loose: and with the final subtlety, so as not to break the arrow, and to make its attraction and extraction difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot reach it right away, then leave it for several days until whatever is around it putsrefies.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat the process: for it is now necessary, if the flow of blood opposes you, to apply what we mentioned from treatment in its chapter: and guard your strength from cutting into a vessel, or nerve, or string.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And use your skill in every way possible to achieve the escape of the arrow: and let it be with ease, tranquility, or delay, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And you must, as you draw the arrow, make it weak according to its figure, according to how it was at the time of the arrow's departure from the bow.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more powerful.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	However, if it is not possible for you, then use what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	However, the arrow that exits from the opposite side of the other part, or has already proceeded from it towards the outside: it causes the end of the arrow to be bent due to the tension from the upper part of the nearby skin, and you will see it sticking out: so dry it above, and make the cut according to the amount that the pincers can grasp.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull it: for indeed, it becomes easy to exit.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If indeed it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness until the arrow impresses itself into the bone and expands itself: then pull it.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let it go for several days: then repeat until it exits.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If there is a wood of the bow (Sagittae) within it, then push it with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	However, if the wood falls and it is necessary to apply an impulse: then insert a sharp instrument into it so that its sharpness enters the end of the bow; afterwards, push it with that.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	However, if the bow is bent, then push it with an instrument entering into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The bow will be straightened by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the bow is damaged, then it is necessary to use a sharp knife to cut off all the corroded part where the string is attached, if you are able to do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of it with what is appropriate for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.
